thread.title: Leicester has been named the worst place in England to raise a family - Leicester Mercury

author: Cathy Buss
title: Leicester has been named the worst place in England to raise a family - Leicester Mercury
text:
Leicester has been named the worst place in England to raise a family Leicester props up list at 137 ahead of East and North Ayrshire Share Comments 
A new report has named Leicester the worst place in England to raise a family. 
Researchers from uSwitch Better Family Life Index looked at 33 elements of family life from GCSE grades, pay levels, weather, fast broadband and access to doctors before compiling a table of 138 council areas. 
Leicester props up the list at 137 ahead of just East Ayrshire and North Ayrshire in Scotland. 
uSwitch, an online and telephone comparison and switching service that helps people to compare prices of products and services, said Leicester had the fourth worst employment in UK, fewer primary schools, high council tax, higher crime levels and poor exam results. Read More Murder inquiry: Woman found dead in car named as 16-year-old Megan Bannister 
It said almost half of parents in the city (45 per cent) said they would consider moving to improve their circumstances and 43 per cent said they worried they were not giving their family the best start in life. 
The report says Leicester has the fourth worst employment rate in the UK and higher council tax at £1,599. 
It says residents in Leicester may also struggle to find childcare as the area has a low number of nurseries per 1,000 residents compared to other areas, and they also spend the least amount of time with their family and friends at just 4 hours 14 minutes each day. 
Just half of pupils achieve five or more A*-C grade GCSE-equivalents and there is one primary school per 4,178 people – compared to one primary school per 773 people in the Shetland Islands. However, the area does enjoy good average download speeds of 37Mbs and low CO2 levels. Read More 
Hertfordshire was declared the best place to raise a family with Cambridgeshire and Central Bedfordshire in second and third places respectively, 
Leicestershire and Rutland finished mid-table at 76. 
uSwitch.com money spokeswoman Tashema Jackson said: "The Better Family Life Index shows that life is far from equal for families across the UK. 
Although there is much to celebrate in many areas, it's not surprising that so many families are thinking about moving to a new region to improve their circumstances. 
"For many consumers, the prospect of increased uncertainty in the run-up to Brexit may be a turning point, leading us to re-evaluate both how we manage our household budgets and how we provide stability for our families in the future. Policymakers would do well to follow suit. 
"With the new government yet to announce its budgetary priorities it is vital that positive changes are made to help give all families fair opportunities no matter where they live - whether it is access to a good education, childcare, housing, GPs or jobs.
